name: politico
text:
When Ruth Bader Ginsburg wanted to be Supreme Court clerk in 1960, she was rejected because of her gender. More than 30 years later she made it to the high court bench herself. 

Here‚Äôs a look back Ginsburg‚Äôs life and legacy. üëá
https://t.co/Xfjc1aoBo1

name: politico
text:
Throughout her life and career, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg was a champion for women‚Äôs rights and equality.

When President Bill Clinton nominated her for the Supreme Court, he called Ginsburg ‚Äúthe Thurgood Marshall of gender equality law‚Äù https://t.co/5fQwhVyXCS https://t.co/PMUWhfCBGS

name: politico
text:
Ginsburg blazed her way into the legal profession, fighting for women's rights the entire way, including in a landmark Supreme Court case
https://t.co/GkIgXOTTM7 https://t.co/RblqPttWQU

name: politico
text:
Reminder: Here's Trump's SCOTUS shortlist. It's headlined by Republican Senators Ted Cruz, Tom Cotton and Josh Hawley.

More names üëá  https://t.co/dWQ31UjXJn

name: politico
text:
Of the six gender-discrimination cases Ginsburg argued in front of an all-male Supreme Court bench the 1970s, she won five
https://t.co/GkIgXOTTM7 https://t.co/oO7fzftAG9

name: politico
text:
In 1980, President Jimmy Carter picked Ginsburg for the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit
https://t.co/wpaug20gJD

name: politico
text:
Ginsburg made it to the nation's highest court in 1993, after being confirmed by a vote of 96-3. She was just the second woman ever to become a Supreme Court justice.
https://t.co/GkIgXOTTM7 https://t.co/viZIn2YcTx

name: politico
text:
Though tagged as a liberal, Ginsburg was an advocate for judicial restraint
https://t.co/GkIgXOTTM7 https://t.co/ZFo2Jf16UZ

name: politico
text:
As the frequency and barbed tone of her dissents increased later in her career, she became a liberal icon, sometimes dubbed ‚ÄúThe Notorious RBG‚Äù
https://t.co/GkIgXOTTM7 https://t.co/obVbDvO8oM

name: politico
text:
In 1980, President Jimmy Carter üì∑ picked her for the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit.

13 years later, with the retirement of #SCOTUS Justice Byron White, Clinton had the opportunity to appoint a justice for the first time and selected Ginsburg https://t.co/WRFRr0RAbT https://t.co/HInCLO5ilf

text:

Thousands of people are gathered here, with hundreds sitting on the steps https://t.co/Cg9oNILOPx üì∑: @evansemones #RBG #SCOTUS https://t.co/kw1xGBLl3m

"Whether you agree or not ... she led an amazing life," he said https://t.co/TvuRl6ZEU4 https://t.co/v6if9xD9cC

name: politico
text:
This is Elisha Bilsborough, a volunteer who's keeping memorial candles lit at the Supreme Court. ‚ÄúI wanted to be around people who are upset, too,‚Äù she said after Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg's death. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really, really crushing.‚Äù

name: politico
text: President Donald Trump is preparing to move swiftly to nominate a new #SCOTUS justice, hoping to deliver a jolt of energy to his beleaguered reelection campaign and give his voters a new focus in a year ravaged by a recession and pandemic https://t.co/4cbN8AczGl

name: politico
text:
Ginsburg's death instantly ignited a power struggle over whether Trump and a GOP-controlled Senate would choose her successor ahead of the election.

Amid questions about the sheer logistics, here are answers on how the coming days are likely to unfold üëáhttps://t.co/EcDKlSKWos

name: politico
text:
(1/3) Does McConnell have enough time to confirm someone‚ùì

‚úÖ Yes, if he has the votes https://t.co/EcDKlSKWos

name: politico
text: (2/3) Since 1975, the Congressional Research Service estimates it's taken an average of 40 days for a #SCOTUS nomin‚Ä¶ https://t.co/Uir1VaifeQ

name: politico
text: (3/3) The nominee has to be approved by the Judiciary Committee before reaching the floor, and Judiciary Committee Chair Lindsey Graham, working closely with McConnell, can tailor a schedule to their liking (üì∑ AP) https://t.co/O6yqJoT6EM https://t.co/pZAosUWDFi

name: politico
text:
(1/3) Can Democrats block a nominee on their own and can Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer deploy any procedural tricks to stop McConnell‚ùì

‚ùå No https://t.co/EcDKlSKWos

name: politico
text: (2/3) There'll always be procedural wrangling, but Dems can't do much without help from at least a few Republicans.‚Ä¶ https://t.co/mYZ3D20VKE

name: politico
text: (3/3) Democrats can raise objections about a potential nominee, raise hell in confirmation hearings and on the floor of the Senate, but ultimately, the committee and McConnell will decide when the key votes occur https://t.co/EcDKlSKWos

name: politico
text:
How many Republicans need to defect to derail a nomination, and who are the ones to watch‚ùì

Democrats need four Republicans to vote with them to block a nominee. That‚Äôs because the GOP holds a 53-47 majority, and VP Mike Pence can break any 50-50 tie https://t.co/EcDKlSKWos
